newsitem.title: USA: California foreclosures drop 12.9 pct - report.
newsitem.headline: California foreclosures drop 12.9 pct - report.

text.p: The number of California foreclosures dropped 12.9 percent in February, reflecting stronger home sales and rising prices, according to a report on Friday.

Lending institutions started foreclosure proceedings against 12,684 homeowners in February, down 12.9 percent from 14,561 for January and down 8.5 percent from 13,868 for February last year, Acxiom/DataQuick Information Systems said.
February was the third month in a row to show a year-over-year decline in the state's number of recorded default notices, the first step of the foreclosure process.

"It's a pretty sure bet that 1997 will be the first year of the 1990s that foreclosures will drop," said Mike Ela, DataQuick's president. "With today's strong home sales and rising prices, more distressed properties are being absorbed by the market before foreclosure proceedings start."
The decline in foreclosure activity was strongest in southern California, which is now recovering from the state's steepest drop in home values, Acxiom/DataQuick said.

Last month's year-over-year drop in foreclosure starts was 39.2 percent in Orange County and 34.2 percent in San Diego County. The default counts in both counties were the lowest in two years, the report said.
Foreclosure activity is still on the rise in California's Central Valley, but the rate should level off this summer if current trends stay in place, the report said.
Acxiom/DataQuick monitors real estate activity nationwide.
